messages: The sun has set on your first day in Dead Paris.
From somewhere below, you hear pounding. Fists on wood. Dozens of them.
The hotel's front barricade shudders but holds. For now.
You realize with cold certainty: when night falls, they come alive.
You survived the night. The pounding stopped around 4 AM.
Through the window, you can see the streets are quieter in daylight.
If you're going to scavenge, daytime is your best chance.
You should explore the hotel first. There might be useful supplies.
A burst of static crackles from somewhere nearby.
For a moment, you think you hear a voice -- military, clipped, professional.
'...evacuation point... CDG... frequency one-two-one...'
Then silence. A radio. If you could build a working radio...
BOOM.
The night sky to the north flares orange. A massive explosion.
The direction of Montmartre. Something big just went up.
The shockwave rattles the windows. Car alarms wail in the distance.
The zombie alert level has increased. They're agitated now.
A tremendous groaning sound echoes from the river.
You hear a crash that shakes the ground. Stone and steel giving way.
The Pont du Carrousel -- the bridge east of here -- has collapsed.
The crossing points are narrowing. Getting across the Seine is harder now.
The unmistakable sound of rotor blades cuts through the dead air.
A military helicopter passes overhead, heading northeast toward CDG.
It's high up, fast, and doesn't slow down. But it means one thing:
The military is still out there. There might still be a way to contact them.
If only you had a working radio and a way to signal them...
The streets are changing.
Where before you'd see a shambler here, a crawler there -- now they
move in groups. Packs. The groaning is constant, a low chorus
from every direction.
Paris is filling up with the dead. If you're going to escape, do it soon.
The zombie alert level has significantly increased.
Day 25. Five days left.
The streets below are a river of shuffling bodies. The horde has
converged on central Paris. Every road, every bridge, every alley
teems with the dead.
If you haven't found an escape route by now, survival means staying
hidden, staying quiet, and counting the hours.
Five more days. You can do this.
A scream pierces the night. Human. Terrified. Then silence.
You can't tell where it came from. There's nothing you can do.
The distant thrum of a helicopter. A parachute blooms against the sky.
A supply crate lands somewhere nearby. You should search the area.
Dark clouds roll in. Rain begins to fall -- hard, cold Parisian rain.
The streets shine wet and the zombies seem sluggish. But you're getting cold.
The rain will pass in a few hours.
A wave of rats surges past your feet, squeaking in panic.
Something behind you spooked them. Or something ahead.
A thud from somewhere above. Then scratching. Something is moving
through the hotel's upper floors.
A car alarm blares to life somewhere down the street.
It wails for thirty seconds, then dies. The silence that follows
is worse. You can hear shuffling feet converging on the sound.
For a moment, the horror fades. The light catches the Seine just right,
the stone buildings glow gold, and Paris is beautiful again.
Then a zombie lurches around a corner and the moment passes.

variants: Spray-painted on a wall: 'GOD LEFT PARIS'
Graffiti on a shopfront: 'THE DEAD WALK. WE RUN.'
Chalked on the pavement: 'ILS SONT PARTOUT' - They are everywhere.
Scratched into a car door: 'DAY 12. STILL ALIVE. NOT FOR LONG.'
Written in blood on a wall: 'NE DESCENDEZ PAS' - Do not go down.
